phrase.content: Unfortunately, there is not a lot of high-quality content that comprehensively covers the sequence merging cases
deals with. Some similar problems appear in

, but they diverge significantly from our use case that it is probably better for us to explain merging ourselves. That being said, this section will be slightly more technical than the previous sections.
There are two distinct types of merges that occur in version control that we need to delineate. The first type of merging is the
. We will cover this in this section. The second type of merging is the
, which concentrates on how commit graphs are merged. We will explain how
handles commit tree merging in one of the next sections.
. You can view the implementation of
To illustrate how it works, we need to visualize a starting state (origin) of a sequence and two changes that occur concurrently.
In our example, our origin is "BCE". Our left change is "BCDE", and our right change is "ABC".

This leaves us with a bit of a predicament. Is the sequence¬†
When a merge operation results in the same sequence, whether merged from the left or from the right (i.e. if the merge operation commutes
and the sequences cannot be merged automatically.
Technical Note: There can sometimes be more than one automatic merge sequence. This can occur when there are repeated
sequences present in one of the reconciled
segments. This discussion is beyond the scope of this article, but
is biased towards "right-sided" reconciliation. Nonetheless, it will automatically merge if an automatic-merge exists using "left-sided" reconciliation. Please see the link to the
are correct, the correct sequence could be
ers from automatic merge technologies. Rather than attempting to guess the merge (or use a last write wins strategy or
, uses user intent to reconcile conflicts. Unlike
are not too cumbersome to resolve. The primary reason for this is that structured data is significantly easier to merge than plain text. Unlike
cannot have syntactic conflicts, only semantic conflicts.
It's easy to see how single-character sequences can be merged. However, the real power of merging emerges when we consider the

of what's being merged. It was entirely our decision to delimit our merge sequences by characters. We could have chosen to merge on a binary level, a word level, or a sentence level. The choice of characters was made because 'BCE', 'ABC', and 'BCDE' did not contain spaces or periods. Strictly speaking, any information can be merged at a binary level, but without structure or a sense of
, the result is likely to be nonsensical.
To illustrate, let's use a merge calculator.

If you experiment a little, you'll find that issues start cropping up when we don't delimit by spaces. Looking at the default sentences, the words "Hello" and "Hi" merge into a conflicted state and become
, when they're delimited on a character level.
Line numbers make a lot of sense for
. Yet, merging on line numbers is not sensible when it comes to merging structured data. Fortunately, a
levels that are suitable for merging. The choice remains with the plugin designer to select the appropriate
Now we finally get to ask the question,
Generally, in programming, we think of colors as combinations of red, green, and blue values. If we considered red, green, and blue as independent variables, we could end up with a
and an effective way to represent the data structure. However, it might lead to some unexpected merge behaviors.
Should changes from the color red to yellow and magenta result in an automatic resolution to the color white? Probably not, but maybe that's the expected behavior of the application.
To resolve this issue, we could opt to not treat each variable as independent, and instead define a

where red, green, and blue are grouped as part of the same category. Hex codes naturally do this. This means that red, green, and blue cannot merge independently of each other. A user would then have to choose either yellow or magenta, or manually resolve the color to something else.
ers from traditional relational data stores. Whether the properties of a category are normalized or denormalized directly affects how the category and its sub-categories are merged and

phrase.content: has a few magic tricks up its sleeve that allow it to perform some pretty remarkable feats. Before explaining the intricate details of how
works, it's important to understand that
Plugins are small UI applications directly managed by
repository as a global redux state store made up of a subset of plugin state stores. The objective of each plugin is to
do one thing and do it well

which outlines the type of content sustained by that plugin. Plugins can read and write to an external upstream plugin's store when the plugin declares the upstream plugin as a dependency. In this sense,
plugins function both like applications and programming modules.

Plugins can also establish relationships between their internal store structures and the external structures of upstream plugins. Plugin developers can specify cascading behaviors in a plugin's schema, making plugins especially valuable for centralizing relational content.
Ultimately, a plugin's state is designed to be used as input to a program called a
Generators transform the state of a plugin (usually into a type of

). The generated code can then be utilized by an application. A generator's output is indifferent to language and environment. In the example below, it is demonstrated how a Typescript output might be generated from the state of a simple localization plugin. It's important to note, there's nothing fundamental about

that necessitates the generated code to be in Typescript or Javascript. Plugins and generators are not directly linked. A plugin may have multiple generators, and generators can take multiple plugin states as input. Generators can produce any type of output.
Plugin Schema -> Plugin State -> Generated Code
is able to exploit the knowledge of a schema to diff and merge any document that has a schema conforming to the
does not really ever see the plugin state as a tree state. Instead it¬†
treats plugin state as an ordered list of key value pairs.¬†
If you have any experience working on merge technology, you likely know that once you can describe a data structure as an ordered list or ordered set, you can merge it!
can convert in both directions between the¬†
Below is an illustration of the two state representations for our example above.
Plugin Schema: KV State <-> Tree State

We will get to the version control side of things soon. We promise! The thing we're really interested in figuring out at this point is if there is anything we can universally guarantee about the code we generate from a generator. If we look back at our first example we can observe something kind of neat now. We can actually determine if an update to the plugin state, is type-compatible with our current content, by looking at the keys of our KV List alone.
To show this, we have to consider three types of changes.

phrase.content: So now our question is actually pretty simple. We want to know if we can safely update version 1 to each new version N (version 2, version 3, and version 4). To do this we are going to ask a simple question, "
are the keys of version 1 all present in the subsequent version's key list?"
We're going to use two tiny pieces of math (set) notation here, "
If you've never seen these symbols before or need a quick refresher, they're quite simple.
A is a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 2, 3, 4}, we would say that A is a subset of B, since 1, 2, and 3 are all present elements in B.
A is NOT a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 3, 4}, we would say that A is¬†
¬†a subset of B, since the element 2 is not present in the elements of B.
So how does this connect back to generating code and type safety? Well if we know the¬†
, we are able to perform type compatibility checks between plugin states, simply by asking the question stated above.
Disclaimer: Additional information from the plugin schema(s), which is not illustrated in either image above, is required for this to be true. If you are interested in a full example,

This is a really powerful trick, since what it allows us to do is make a certain assumption about our content. If we managed to deploy a version of our application that was built with "Version 1" of our floro state, we could safely deploy updated versions of our app to versions 2 or versions 3 with full confidence that we are not causing any bugs without having to recompile our entire application. If however, we were to swap out our content from version 1, to version 4, we would likely crash if a user ever visited a page calling the key¬†
" version of the app. We therefore would not ever deploy version 4.
By performing this simple set check, we've essentially done the work of a (
¬†supports relationships between the substructures of a plugin's state. How it accomplishes this is through references. The keys of the¬†
pairs are the actual pointer values in references. While this syntax could be used to point to any structure in a tree-state, it only makes sense to hold references to the elements of a set.
To further explain, we're going to build upon our prior example of our

plugin. First we're going to refactor our schema to include a second set called "Languages". In this example, we're syntactically treating Languages as a separate plugin. However, it is perfectly fine to have multiple root level sets in the same plugin.

If you're overwhelmed by this change, don't be. It's actually not nearly as complicated as it may look at first glance. If we look in our Translations data structure, you'll notice we abandoned our "Locale" property, which previously served as our
. We updated our data structure to now use a¬†
We also set a cascading option "onDelete" to "delete", on our¬†

¬†property. The alternative cascading delete option value is "nullify". You probably can guess the difference at this point but if the "onDelete" value of a reference type is "delete", the set element containing that reference will be deleted, when the reference is deleted. For example, if we were to remove the Languages' element with the Code equal to "ZH" from the Languages list, our Translation element with the reference¬†

¬†would also be removed. However, if the "onDelete" property were set to "nullify", our Translation element would not be removed, we would be left will a null pointer though (ie. the value of LanguageReference would be set to equal to null). It is important to note that¬†
nullifying our reference is not possible in this example, since the LanguageReference property is the
There's actually one more cascading behavior not commonly recognized in the world of relational databases that
expanding a set by the boundaries of another set
Imagine we wanted to add a new language (Spanish) to our plugin. If this were a relational database, we might add a new column "Spanish" to our Languages' table.
has a slightly different way of handling this relationship. We specify a property in our
of our set is a reference to another set it can be bounded by.
cannot bind sets to other nested sets, only root-level
Once we add Spanish to our language list,
will automatically cascade all of the
state to include a reference to Spanish as well.
The above image illustrates how cascading enforces bounded sets. Since Translations are bounded by Languages (due to the

of Translations being a reference to Languages), we can guarantee that for every LocalizedKeys element, for each of its Translations element there will always be an element with a reference to each Language element. This becomes particularly important when we get into merging states, which necessitates cascading states.

There is unfortunately no such thing as a perfect merge algorithm. There are however, less correct merge algorithms, and more correct merge algorithms.
And that's the way that plugin diffing really works. While the user interfaces with the plugin via a user interface and alters the plugin's
through the GUI, the plugin interfaces with
through its keys. In fact all that is communicated to a plugin about a diff, is which keys were removed and which keys were added.

The idea that all a document diff requires is two views, the before, and the after, as well as the keys that were removed from the before state and the keys that were to the after state is the fundamental idea of document diffing.

In the next section we discuss merging and data granularity. One key thing to know at this point, is that if something can be diffed (meaningfully) then it can also be merged (meaningfully)... even when conflicts arise.

Finally, we can return back to our Localization example to see how we can apply diffing to our plugin states.
The big philosophical question in diffing is how do you produce a meaningful diff?
Unfortunately, diffing documents is highly subjective to the task at hand. However,
has a couple of tricks for making good diffs easy for plugin developers to create.

The key thing to know about LCS, is that the opposite of the LCS is the diff, which makes sense when you think about it for a moment. The LCS tells us what is the same between two sequences, by comparing the LCS to the before sequence and after sequence, we can easily determine what was

phrase.content: The diff calculator below demonstrates this process.
wouldn't be much of a version control system if it didn't have diffs. But before explaining how diffs work in
, it's best to take a step back and do a quick overview of diffing in general.

Diffing is the process of describing how one sequence transforms into a different sequence. Typically diffing involves finding the most concise way to transform between the two sequences. For sake of consistency, we will be discussing the two states of a diff as the "before" state and the "after" state. Although there is no real direction in diffing.
The algorithm used for diffing is the
or LCS algorithm. There's a plethora of YouTube videos giving explanations of how to find the LCS for two sequences

, so we will spare you. However, to help build intuition for the algorithm, we've provided you an LCS string calculator that delimits on characters. Feel free to type around and see how the LCS changes, when you change either of the strings.

The above image illustrates how cascading enforces bounded sets. Since Translations are bounded by Languages (due to the primary key of Translations being a reference to Languages), we can guarantee that for every LocalizationKey element, for each of its Translations element there will always be an element with a reference to each Language element. This becomes particularly important when we get into merging states, which necessitates cascading states.
Conceptually, we've now created for ourselves, what is essentially an excel spreadsheet.

If you're overwhelmed by this change, don't be. It's actually not nearly as complicated as it may look at first glance. If we look in our Translations data structure, you'll notice we abandoned our "Locale" property, which previously served as our primary key. We updated our data structure to now use a
We also set a cascading option "onDelete" to "delete", on our

property. The alternative cascading delete option value is "nullify". You probably can guess the difference at this point but if the "onDelete" value of a reference type is "delete", the set element containing that reference will be deleted, when the reference is deleted. For example, if we were to remove the Languages' element with the Code equal to "ZH" from the Languages list, our Translation element with the reference

¬†would also be removed. However, if the "onDelete" property were set to "nullify", our Translation element would not be removed, we would be left will a null pointer though (ie. the value of LanguageReference would be set to equal to null). It is important to note that
nullifying our reference is not possible in this example, since the LanguageReference property is the primary key of the Translations set.
There's actually one more cascading behavior not commonly recognized in the world of relational databases that
expanding a set by the boundaries of another set
Imagine we wanted to add a new language (Spanish) to our plugin. If this were a relational database, we might add a new column "Spanish" to our Languages' table.

cannot bind sets to other nested sets, only root-level
Once we add Spanish to our language list,
will automatically cascade all of the LocalizedKeys in the plugins state to include a reference to Spanish as well.

Next, we add the added characters in the diff to the LCS, which gives us the

phrase.content: The diff calculator below demonstrates this process.
wouldn't be much of a version control system if it didn't have diffs. But before explaining how diffs work in
, it's best to take a step back and do a quick overview of diffing in general.

Diffing is the process of describing how one sequence transforms into a different sequence. Typically diffing involves finding the most concise way to transform between the two sequences. For sake of consistency, we will be discussing the two states of a diff as the "before" state and the "after" state. Although there is no real direction in diffing.
The algorithm used for diffing is the
or LCS algorithm. There's a plethora of YouTube videos giving explanations of how to find the LCS for two sequences

, so we will spare you. However, to help build intuition for the algorithm, we've provided you an LCS string calculator that delimits on characters. Feel free to type around and see how the LCS changes, when you change either of the strings.

The above image illustrates how cascading enforces bounded sets. Since Translations are bounded by Languages (due to the primary key of Translations being a reference to Languages), we can guarantee that for every LocalizationKey element, for each of its Translations element there will always be an element with a reference to each Language element. This becomes particularly important when we get into merging states, which necessitates cascading states.
Conceptually, we've now created for ourselves, what is essentially an excel spreadsheet.

If you're overwhelmed by this change, don't be. It's actually not nearly as complicated as it may look at first glance. If we look in our Translations data structure, you'll notice we abandoned our "Locale" property, which previously served as our primary key. We updated our data structure to now use a
We also set a cascading option "onDelete" to "delete", on our

property. The alternative cascading delete option value is "nullify". You probably can guess the difference at this point but if the "onDelete" value of a reference type is "delete", the set element containing that reference will be deleted, when the reference is deleted. For example, if we were to remove the Languages' element with the Code equal to "ZH" from the Languages list, our Translation element with the reference

¬†would also be removed. However, if the "onDelete" property were set to "nullify", our Translation element would not be removed, we would be left will a null pointer though (ie. the value of LanguageReference would be set to equal to null). It is important to note that
nullifying our reference is not possible in this example, since the LanguageReference property is the primary key of the Translations set.
There's actually one more cascading behavior not commonly recognized in the world of relational databases that
expanding a set by the boundaries of another set
Imagine we wanted to add a new language (Spanish) to our plugin. If this were a relational database, we might add a new column "Spanish" to our Languages' table.
has a slightly different way of handling this relationship. We specify a property in our schema, that our set is a
This only works, when the primary key of our set is a reference to another set it can be bounded by.
cannot bind sets to other nested sets, only root-level
Once we add Spanish to our language list,
will automatically cascade all of the LocalizedKeys in the plugins state to include a reference to Spanish as well.
supports relationships between the substructures of a plugin's state. How it accomplishes this is through references. The keys of the
pairs are the actual pointer values in references. While this syntax could be used to point to any structure in a tree-state, it only makes sense to hold references to the elements of a set.

To further explain, we're going to build upon our prior example of our LocalizedKeys plugin. First we're going to refactor our schema to include a second set called "Languages". In this example, we're syntactically treating Languages as a separate plugin. However, it is perfectly fine to have multiple root level sets in the same plugin.

displayValue.content: this is a useful unit test to examine

phrase.content: Disclaimer: Additional information from the plugin schema(s), which is not illustrated in either image above, is required for this to be true. If you are interested in a full example,

This is a really powerful trick, since what it allows us to do is make a certain assumption about our content. If we managed to deploy a version of our application that was built with "Version 1" of our

state, we could safely deploy updated versions of our app to versions 2 or versions 3 with full confidence that we are not causing any bugs without having to recompile our entire application. If however, we were to swap out our content from version 1, to version 4, we would likely crash if a user ever visited a page calling the key
" version of the app. We therefore would not ever deploy version 4.
By performing this simple set check, we've essentially done the work of a (

So now our question is actually pretty simple. We want to know if we can safely update version 1 to each new version N (version 2, version 3, and version 4). To do this we are going to ask a simple question, "
are the keys of version 1 all present in the subsequent version's key list?"
We're going to use two tiny pieces of math (set) notation here, "
If you've never seen these symbols before or need a quick refresher, they're quite simple.
A is a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 2, 3, 4}, we would say that A is a subset of B, since 1, 2, and 3 are all present elements in B.
A is NOT a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 3, 4}, we would say that A is
a subset of B, since the element 2 is not present in the elements of B.
So how does this connect back to generating code and type safety? Well if we know the
, we are able to perform type compatibility checks between plugin states, simply by asking the question stated above.

We will get to the version control side of things soon. We promise! The thing we're really interested in figuring out at this point is if there is anything we can universally guarantee about the code we generate from a generator. If we look back at our first example we can observe something kind of neat now. We can actually determine if an update to the plugin state, is type-compatible with our current content, by looking at the keys of our KV List alone.
To show this, we have to consider three types of changes.

children.content: - We will add a new Translation phrase to our Localized Keys
, and provide English and Chinese Translations for the new phrase
- We will change the content value of our Localized Key for the phrase
- We will remove the Chinese translation for our

phrase.content: has a few magic tricks up it's sleeve that allow it to do some pretty remarkable things. Before explaining the low-level details of how
works, the most important thing to understand about
is that it uses something called
¬†Plugins are small UI applications directly managed by
repository as¬†a global redux state store composed of a subset of plugin state stores. The goal of each plugin is to¬†
do one thing and do it well

which describes the type of the content persisted by that plugin. Plugins are able to read and write to an external upstream plugin's store when the plugin requires the upstream plugin as a dependency. In this sense,
plugins behave both like applications as well as programming modules.

¬†Plugins can also hold relationships between their internal store structures as well as the external structures of upstream plugins. Plugin developers can define cascading behaviors in a plugin's schema. This makes plugins particularly useful for centralizing relational content.¬†
Ultimately, a plugin's state is meant to be consumed as input to a program called a
¬†Generators transform the state of a plugin (usually into a type of

). This generated code can then be consumed by an application. A generator's output is language and environment agnostic. In the example below, we demonstrate how a Typescript output may be generated from the state of a simple localization plugin. It's important to note, there is nothing fundamental about

that requires the generated code to be Typescript or Javascript. Plugins and generators are not directly coupled. A plugin may have multiple generators and generators may take multiple plugin states as input. Generators can produce any type of output.
Plugin Schema -> Plugin State -> Generated Code
is able to exploit the knowledge of a schema to diff and merge any document that has a schema conforming to the
does not really ever see the plugin state as a tree state. Instead it
treats plugin state as an ordered list of key value pairs.
If you have any experience working on merge technology, you likely know that once you can describe a data structure as an ordered list or ordered set, you can merge it!
can convert in both directions between the
Below is an illustration of the two state representations for our example above.
Plugin Schema: KV State <-> Tree State
Disclaimer: This is not exactly the syntax floro uses and is a simplification of the actual floro syntax (it has some small inaccuracies).
So what is this bizarre path key syntax?
It's basically a path to the struct (the
¬†syntax is used to select from a specific¬†
¬†is the root for the plugin, so it gets wrapped by
>" bit. What it basically says is look in the list (LocalizedKeys) and search for the first object with a property called "
" that has a value equal to "
". If you look in the plugin schema, you might notice that the
property of the LocalizedKeys set has the property value pair¬†
You can think of this property as a primary key for that structure.

At this point in the iteration, we've successfully traversed to the "Welcome Hero" struct. Next we select the ".Translations" part of the path and have another list, this time with two structures at the current nesting level. Again, we see the
>". So we search the list for the first element with a
All the Intermediate state representation is, is a list of
By applying our list of ordered key pairs, we can reconstruct a state tree. Conversely, we can recreate any ordered key pair list, from any state tree.
